<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_fs_grow_:
```c
static int lfs_fs_grow_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_size_t block_count) {
    int err;

    if (block_count == lfs->block_count) {
        return 0;
    }

    
#ifndef LFS_SHRINKNONRELOCATING
    // shrinking is not supported
    LFS_ASSERT(block_count >= lfs->block_count);
#endif
#ifdef LFS_SHRINKNONRELOCATING
    if (block_count < lfs->block_count) {
        err = lfs_fs_traverse_(lfs, lfs_shrink_checkblock, &block_count, true);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }
#endif

    lfs->block_count = block_count;

    // fetch the root
    lfs_mdir_t root;
    err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &root, lfs->root);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // update the superblock
    lfs_superblock_t superblock;
    lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_get(lfs, &root, LFS_MKTAG(0x7ff, 0x3ff, 0),
            LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_INLINESTRUCT, 0, sizeof(superblock)),
            &superblock);
    if (tag < 0) {
        return tag;
    }
    lfs_superblock_fromle32(&superblock);

    superblock.block_count = lfs->block_count;

    lfs_superblock_tole32(&superblock);
    err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &root, LFS_MKATTRS(
            {tag, &superblock}));
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_get(lfs, &root, LFS_MKTAG(0x7ff, 0x3ff, 0),
            LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_INLINESTRUCT, 0, sizeof(superblock)),
            &superblock);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario:
The code passes the address of a local lfs_superblock_t object and encodes its size in the tag (LFS_MKTAG(..., sizeof(superblock))). If lfs_dir_get uses the provided tag/length to limit any memory copies into the supplied buffer (or otherwise validates lengths against sizeof(superblock)), then there is no out‑of‑bounds access and Rule 21.17 is not violated. 

Potential violation scenario: if lfs_dir_get ignores/overrides the encoded length and instead copies a larger amount (for example, using a stored on‑disk length or an unbounded memcpy/memmove) into &superblock, then that would result in an access beyond the bounds of superblock and would violate Rule 21.17.
